title: PCT 21: A poor Assiniboine becomes chief
author: Adam Sakewew

sentences.original: kîtahtawê opwâsimowak mihcêtiwak; mînah mikiwâhpah mihcêtinwah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê opwâsîmowak mihcêtiwak mîna mîkiwâhpa mihcêtinwa
sentences.english: Once upon a time there were many Assiniboine Sioux; and there were many tents.
One Assiniboine, a young man, was very poor.
None of his kinsfolk were living.
“Truly I am wretched,” he thought.
Then he asked his wife, who was nearly an old woman:

sentences.original: awiyak cî kiwâhkomâkan pimâtisiw, kôhtâwiy kikâwiy kisîm kistês kimis ?
sentences.english: “Are any of your kinsfolk alive, your father, your mother,  your younger brother or sister, your elder brother, your elder sister?
Is none of them alive?” he asked her.

sentences.original: êkwah omis îtik : mitoni nam âwiyak.
sentences.english: She answered him, “They are all gone.”
“Then truly we are pitiable.
Take heart and work.

sentences.original: niya mînah nik-âhkamêyimon, ôtah kâ-wîkihkêmoyahk kit-âtoskawâyahkok ta-pamihâyahkok, ôma itah kâ-wîkihkêmoyahk.
sentences.english: I too shall take courage, and we shall work for the people here among whom we dwell.”
“Yes,” she answered him.
In winter then they worked.
In spring, when his people moved camp, he walked about.

sentences.original: matokahpihk pôtê miskam : mîkwanah êkwah pîwâpiskwah.
sentences.text: matokahpihk pôti miskam mîkwana êkwa pîwâpiskwa
sentences.english: In an abandoned lodge he found something: some feathers and some pieces of metal.
He took the things home and gave them to his wife.
“Take these things and save them up,” he told her.

sentences.original: êkwah manimisâskwatwêw; ahcâpiyah mînah osîhêw; nîsitanaw niyânanosâp osîhtâw acosisah.
sentences.text: êkwa manimisâskwatwêw ahcâpiya mîna osîhêw nîsitanaw niyânanosâp osîhtâw acosisa
sentences.english: Then he gathered spruce-wood; he made a bow and twenty-five  arrows.
Then he put feathers on the arrows.
He completed it all.
Then he sewed a quiver.

sentences.original: êkwah ispatinâhk itohtêw, ê-wîhkwêstêyikih mîkiwahpah ê-kitâpahtahk.
sentences.text: êkwa ispatinâhk itohtêw ê-wîhkwêstêyiki mîkiwâhpa ê-kitâpahtahk
sentences.english: Then he went to the top of a hill and looked at the lodges which stood in a circle.
He saw a single lodge which stood in the center.
He thought, “That man is rich.
Suppose I go ask him;

sentences.original: nka-ntaw-âtâmâw atimwah pêyak ôh ôhci nîpisisah, itêyihtam.
sentences.english: I shall buy a dog from him with these arrows,” he thought.

sentences.original: itohtêw êh-otâkosiniyik, mihcêt êh-wâpamât atimwah, otâpânâskwah, atim-ôtâpânâskwah.
sentences.text: itohtêw ê-otâkosiniyik mihcêt ê-wâpamât atimwa otâpânâskwa atimo-otâpânâskwa
sentences.english: He went there in the evening, and saw a great many dogs and sleds, dog-sleds.
When he entered the lodge, there sat a man.
“Come in, young man,” said the other to him;
“Come, let him eat.”
He was given to eat.
When he had finished his meal, he gave the things to the other.

sentences.original: ôh ôhci kâ-pêy-itohtêyân acosisah, êh-itêyihtamân, k-oh-pîhtokêyân.
sentences.english: “I have come here on account of these arrows, thinking perhaps he would give me a puppy;' that is why I have come to our tent.”
“Yes, I shall give you some.”
There were seven of them.
“These puppies have already opened their eyes;

sentences.original: êwakonik kimiyitin; êkwah okâwiwâwa, acimosisak okâwîwâwah.
sentences.english: I give you these; also the dam, the puppies' mother.
I thank you for having come and given me these things.”

sentences.original: êkwah iskwêwak postamohêwak kiskânakwah ôhi k-âtâwêwiht.
sentences.text: êkwa iskwêwak postamôhêwak kiskânakwa ôhi kâ-atâwêwiht
sentences.english: Then the women harnessed the female that had been sold.
It was already close to night.
He took them home, carrying all the puppies.
The bitch ran behind him.
He called to his wife, “Come out!”
She came out of the lodge.
“Tie her up.
Let her suckle these puppies of hers.”
She tied her up and fed her.
The dog brought up its young.
Then again he cut some spruce-sticks.

sentences.original: kêyâpic êko-tahto, nîsitanaw niyânanosâp âsay min ôsihtâw.
sentences.text: kêyâpic êko-tahto nîsitanaw niyânanosâp âsay mîna osihtâw
sentences.english: Again the same number,  twenty-five, he made.

sentences.original: êh-kîsihtât, âsay minah ispatinâhk itohtêw. âsay minah kitâpahtam mîkiwahpah.
sentences.text: ê-kîsihtât âsay mîna ispatinâhk itohtêw âsay mîna kitâpahtam mîkiwâhpa
sentences.english: When he had finished them, again he went to the hill-top and looked down at the tents.
“Down there are many women at work,” he thought;

sentences.original: êkotê nika-kiwokân, itêyihtam awah kâ-kitimâkisit opwâsîmôw.
sentences.english: “There I shall visit,” thought the poor Stony.

sentences.original: kiyokêw êh-otâkosiniyik, êh-pimiwitât ôhi kâ-kîh-osîhtât acosisah.
sentences.text: kiyokêw ê-otâkosiniyik ê-pimiwitât ôhi kâ-kî-osîhtât acosisa
sentences.english: He made his visit at dusk, carrying along the arrows he had made.

sentences.original: ê-takohtêt mîkiwâhpihk, tawâw, itik ôhi nâpêwah.
sentences.english: When he came to the tent, “Come in,” said the man to him.
He entered; this time too he was given food.

sentences.original: ê-kîsi-mîcisot, hâw, oskinîkiw! nama wîhkâc kikiwokân.
sentences.english: When he had eaten, “Now, young man, it is not your habit to go a-visiting.
No doubt you have called here with something in mind.”
“It is that I have come to trade you these things which I am carrying with me, if you have the trade.
'The women have  hide-flatteners, hide-scrapers, hatchets, files, and knives,' was my thought; 'Suppose I go buy them from him,' was my thought.”
“Yes, these things are here,” said the man to him.
He gave him all the things he had come to buy.
He took them home and gave them to his wife.

sentences.original: nah ôhi; kiy ôh âyâ; nahastâh; kanawêyihtah;
sentences.english: “Here, take these things; do you keep them; put them away and take care of them;
we are altogether too destitute,” said he to his wife.
“Yes,” his wife answered him; “Thank you.”

sentences.original: âsay mînah otinam misâskwatwah; âsay minah nîsitanaw niyânanosâp osîhtâw.
sentences.text: âsay mîna otinam misâskwatwa âsay mîna nîsitanaw niyânanosâp osîhtâw
sentences.english: Again he took some spruce-sticks; again he made twenty-five.
He finished them.

sentences.original: âsay minah êw-otâkosiniyik ê-wîhkwêstêyikih mîkiwâhpah kitâpahtam :
sentences.text: âsay mîna ê-otâkosiniyik ê-wîhkwêstêyiki mîkiwâhpa kitâpahtam
sentences.english: Again at nightfall he looked at the tents standing in a circle.
There in the center stood a lodge.

sentences.original: itêyihtam : nâhah okimâw manitôwiw; nihtâ-nanâtawihiwêw, itêyihtam.
sentences.english: He thought: “Yonder chief has spirit-power; he is a great healer.”
He went there; at nightfall he entered.
“Come in,” he was told.
Again he was given food.

sentences.original: êh-itâpit askotâskopisonihk, pôtih wâpahtam pâskisikanah nistoh.
sentences.text: ê-itâpit askotâskopisonihk pôti wâpahtam pâskisikana nisto
sentences.english: When he looked at the wooden beams along the wall, there he saw three guns.
He was given food.

sentences.original: êh-kîsi-mîcisot, miyâw pâskisikan pêyak, êh-atâwêt ôh ôhci acosisah, êkwah kaskitêw pîhcipihkwânah ê-sâkaskinêyit, êkwah môsasiniyah nîsitanaw, êkwah cahkisêhikanah nîso, êkwah kêtahikanah nîso.
sentences.text: ê-kîsi-mîcisot miyâw pâskisikan pêyak ê-atâwêt ôhi ohci acosisa êkwa kaskitêw pîhcipihkwâna ê-sâkaskinêyit êkwa môsasiniya nîsitanaw êkwa cahkisêhikana nîso êkwa kêtahikana nîso
sentences.english: When he had eaten, he was given a gun, which he bought with those arrows, also some gun-powder, a powder-horn full of it, twenty bullets, two flints, and two ramrods.
“I thank you, young man, for giving me these,” he said to him.
He went home.
“So do you save these things,” he told his wife.

sentences.original: âsay minah osîhtâw acosisah nîsitanaw, êyôkonih nik-âyân, êh-itêyihtahk.
sentences.text: âsay mîna osîhtâw acosisa nîsitanaw ê-itêyihtahk
sentences.english: Again he made twenty arrows, “These I shall keep,” being his plan.
He finished them.

sentences.original: êkwah ôk acimosisak misikitiwak; êkwah âsay takwâkin;
sentences.text: êkwa ôki acimosisak misikitiwak êkwa âsay takwâkin
sentences.english: Now those puppies had grown up and it was autumn;
they were already quite big.
The woman broke them to harness.
She hitched up those young dogs.

sentences.original: êkwah kêkâc pipon. êkwah mitoni kisin.
sentences.text: êkwa kêkâc pipon êkwa mitoni kisin
sentences.english: Then it was nearly winter, and very cold.

sentences.original: kêkâc êh-pipohk, paskêpiciwak êh-nîsicik owîkimâkanah awa kâ-kitimâkisit.
sentences.text: kêkâc ê-pipohk paskêpiciwak ê-nîsicik owîkimâkana awa kâ-kitimâkisit
sentences.english: When it was nearly winter, the two, the poor man and his wife, moved camp away from the others.

sentences.original: sakâw otihtam êh-ihkatawayik, wâsakâm ê-sakâyik, mihtah êh-micêniyikih, mînah mostoswah êh-mihcêtiyit.
sentences.text: sakâw otihtam ê-ihkatawâyik wâsakâm ê-sakâyik mihta ê-mihcêniyiki mîna mostoswa ê-mihcêtiyit
sentences.english: He came to a wood with an open space in the middle with woods all round, where there was plenty of fuel and where the buffalos were many.
He killed a buffalo.

sentences.original: êkwah osîhtâw wîkih, mîkiwâhp, mihtikowâhp ê-misâyik.
sentences.text: êkwa osîhtâw wîki mîkiwâhp mihtikowâhp ê-misâyik
sentences.english: Then he built his dwelling, a large wooden house.
He took all the meat.
Then every day he hunted; every day he made a killing.

sentences.original: atimwah âpacihêwak ayênâniw; kahkiyaw otinamwak wiyâs.
sentences.text: atimwa âpacihêwak ayinânêw kahkiyaw otinamwak wiyâs
sentences.english: They used the eight dogs; they took all the meat.

sentences.original: mînah wanîhikêw mistiko-wanîhikanah, mahîhkanah êh-nôcihât, nanâtohk atâwâkanah ê-nipahât wanihikanihk.
sentences.text: mîna wanihikêw mistiko-wanihikana mahîhkana ê-nôcihât nanâtohk atâwâkana ê-nipahât wanihikanihk
sentences.english: Also he trapped with wooden traps, trying for wolves, and killed all kinds of fur-bearing beasts in his traps.

sentences.original: pêyak kîsikâw âskaw mitâtaht ayiwâkês nipahêw mahîhkanah.
sentences.text: pêyak kîsikâw âskaw mitâtaht ayiwâkês nipahêw mahîhkana
sentences.english: Often he killed more than ten wolves in a day.

sentences.original: mihcêt osîhtâw cêsipicikanah, wiyâs êkotah êh-akotât, wiyâs êh-akotât cêsipicikanihk.
sentences.text: mihcêt osîhtâw cêsipicikana wiyâs êkota ê-akotât wiyâs ê-akotât cêsipicikanihk
sentences.english: He built many drying-frames,  on which he hung his meat.
The woman, too, worked bravely.
It would be almost dawn when they quit work, so busy were they.
The warm weather was already coming on.
“I suppose I had better make a sled now,” he thought.

sentences.original: osîhêw atim-otâpânâskwah, êh-pasahwât mistikwah, napakitâpânâskwah êh-osîhât.
sentences.text: osîhêw atimo-otâpânâskwa ê-pasahwât mistikwa napakitâpânâskwa ê-osîhât
sentences.english: He built a dog-sled with split trees, a flat dog-sled.
When he had finished it, he tied it up.
sentences.footnote: LB on {tahpotêw}:  Probably {takohtêw}: “he came back to the house.”

sentences.original: êkotah napakâhtikohk ahêw mostoswêyânah mînah mahîhkaniwêyânah, nanâtohk atâwâkanah.
sentences.text: êkota napakâhtikohk ahêw mostoswayâna mîna mahîhkaniwayâna nanâtohk atâwâkana
sentences.english: On the boards of it he put buffalo-robes, wolfskins, and all kinds of furs.
He went off to see the trader in his house.
He came there.

sentences.original: haw, pîhtokah; asam kitêmak, itik okimâwah.
sentences.english: “Well, bring them in; feed your dogs,” said the agent to him.
He brought them into the shed and fed them.

sentences.original: êkwah awa oskinîkiw kâ-kitimâkisit, awînah itah êh-ayât êh-pêw-âh-ohci-sipwêhtêyan ? itik.
sentences.english: Then they asked the poor young man, “Who is there at the places you come from?”
“Only my wife and I.

sentences.original: mistahi nitayân wiyâs wiyinwah pimiyah atâwâkanak.
sentences.english: I have a great deal of meat, fats, grease, and fur.
If you need meat, I can give you some.”
“Yes, I want all the food you have.
I can take it all,” the other told him;
“How many wagonloads is it?”
“One, two, ten wagonloads.”
“Well! You are saying a great deal.

sentences.original: ahpôh ôtênaw êy-otihtamân, nama wîhkâc mitâtaht sâkaskinêwak otâpânâskwak.
sentences.english: Even when I come to a town, there are never ten loads.”
“Yes.”

sentences.original: êkwah êh-pêyakoyan, kiwîkimâkan ê-nîsiyêk, mistahi kâ-ntawêyimacik otâpânâskwak.
sentences.english: “For you and your wife alone that is quite a few sleds.”
“Yes,” answered the other, “and that is not all.
It is for meat alone that I need ten sleds.

sentences.original: tahto kêkway atâwâkanah mêstawatâtwâwi kôskinîkîmak, êkoyikohk nka-pêy-itohtân ta-pêw-otinikêyân.
sentences.english: When your helpers have carted away all the furs, then I shall come to take my pay.

sentences.original: anohc wiyah pêyakwasâkay kika-miyin, kaskitêwêkin êkwah pêhpêsâpowêyân.
sentences.english: Today just give me one dress-length, black cloth and striped cloth.

sentences.original: êkwah kiyah! pêyakwayôwinis wêmistikôsiw-ayôwinisah, astotin, êkwah kiyah kiminihkwêwin kâ-miywâsik, êkwah pêyakonisk mihkwêkin, êkwah cistêmâw;
sentences.english: And one suit of your white-man's clothes, a hat, and some of your own good liquor, one fathom of red flannel, and some tobacco;
that is all you need to give me.
When I come back to collect, I shall tell you the rest.”

sentences.original: kîwêw. owîkimâkanah otihtêw. pêyakwâ nipâw; owîkimâkanah otihtêw.
sentences.text: kîwêw owîkimâkana otihtêw pêyakwâw nipâw owîkimâkana otihtêw
sentences.english: He went home to his wife, sleeping one night on the way.
He gave her the things.
“Stick to your work;
make yourself a dress of this,” he told her.

sentences.original: kakwêyahôw ê-kaskikwâtahk aw îskwêw oskotâkay ôma kaskitêwêkin, otâsa mînah aw îskwêw, wanakwayah mînah.
sentences.text: kakwêyâhow ê-kaskikwâtahk awa iskwêw oskotâkay ôma kaskitêwêkin otâsa mîna awa iskwêw wanakwaya mîna
sentences.english: The woman worked busily, sewing a dress for herself out of the black broadcloth, as well as some gaiters and sleeves.
She put on her new clothes.

sentences.original: hâ, pakwahtêh ômah, itêw owîkimâkanah, ôma wâpowêyân.
sentences.english: “Good, now wear this round your waist,” he said to his wife, “this robe.”

sentences.original: ê-kîsi-postayôwinisêt aw îskwêw, êkwah awa nâpêw postayôwinisêw, wêmistikôsiw-ayôwinisah; astotin, postatotinêw.
sentences.text: ê-kîsi-postayôwinisêt awa iskwêw êkwa awa nâpêw postayôwinisêw wêmistikôsiwi-ayôwinisa astotin postastotinêw
sentences.english: When the woman had dressed up, the man also dressed up in white-man's clothes, and put on his hat.
Now they were no longer poor.

sentences.original: otinam; oyâkanihk iskotêwâpoy sîkinam, êkwah êyakô êh-minihkwêcik.
sentences.text: otinam oyâkanihk iskotêwâpoy sîkinam êkwa êwako ê-minihkwêcik
sentences.english: He took the whiskey and poured it into a bowl and then they drank it.
When it was almost daylight,
sentences.footnote: LB's translation merged into first sentence of next paragraph.

sentences.english: “There, that will do; let us stop drinking;
we have too much work ahead;
some people are coming, Frenchmen, to fetch meat.
Set bravely to work.

sentences.original: osâm mistahi kikitimâkisinânaw, êkâ awiyak êh-wahkomâyahk.
sentences.english: We are altogether too poor, having no kinspeople.

sentences.original: êwak ôhci kâ-kîh-atâwêyân atimwak, êwakonik kit-ôtêmiyahk.
sentences.english: It was for this I bought the dogs, to be our beasts of burden.
Take heart and work bravely;
I too shall work stoutly at getting furs.”
Accordingly, three days later six sleds arrived.
“Bring only meat;

sentences.original: atâwâkanak pêyak otâpânâsk ka-pêsiwâwâwak, niyânan otâpânâsk wiyâs êkwah.
sentences.english: one load of fur you will bring, and five loads of meat.”

sentences.original: êh-takosihkik ôkih wêmistikôsiwak, êkwah pôsihtâwak wiyâs;
sentences.text: ê-takosihkik ôki wêmistikôsiwak êkwa pôsihtâwak wiyâs
sentences.english: When those Frenchmen arrived, they loaded meat;

sentences.original: namoya âpihtaw otinamwak; namoya ahpôh âpihtaw atâwâkanah otinêwak.
sentences.text: namôya âpihtaw otinamwak namôya ahpô âpihtaw atâwâkana otinêwak
sentences.english: they did not take half of it, and they took not even half of the pelts.
They went back.
They arrived yonder at the trading-house.
Then the agent was told:
“Perhaps twenty sleds will be filled.

sentences.original: mistahi wiyâs, pimiyah mînah, wiyinwah mînah.
sentences.english: There is much meat, grease, and fat.

sentences.original: mâskôc mistahê kik-êtêyihtên, okimâw, wâpahtamanê, pêyak ayîsiyiniw kita-miyisk ahtayah, nanâtohk mîciwin.
sentences.english: No doubt you will think it a great deal for one man to give you in fur and various kinds of food.
He has grown rich, all by himself with his wife.

sentences.original: mihtah êh-wîkicik tâpiskôc ôtênaw ayîsiyiniw wêtihtahkih.
sentences.english: The firewood where they live looks like a town, as one approaches.

sentences.original: namoya wîhkâc kahkiyaw sâkaskinêwak otâpânâskwak, êkwah oki nikotwâsik otâpânâskwak kahkiyaw kâ-sâkaskinêcik.
sentences.english: Never are all the sleds full, and there are the six sleds all loaded.

sentences.original: êkwah nânitaw nîsitanaw otâpânâskwak ta-sipwêhtêyân kahkiyaw nika-pêtân tahtoh kâ-ayâcik mîciwin ahtayah minah.
sentences.english: If I go off with some twenty sleds, I can bring all the meat they have and the furs.”
“So that is the way you fared?”
“Yes.”
“You will go off with twenty sleds.

sentences.original: kîspin sâkaskinêcih, kahkiyaw sâkaskinêtwâwih, tâpiskôc mihcêt otênawah êh-wâpahtamân nik-êtêyihtên.
sentences.english: When they are all full, I shall think I am beholding many villages.
Very well, be off.”
So twenty sleds started out.
“When you have loaded it all, let them set out and come here.
I should like to see his wife who does so much work.”
They arrived; and all the sleds were loaded full.

sentences.original: êkwah awah otêmah atimwah aw ôpwâsimôw ayênâniw kahkiyaw otâpahêw, atâwâkanah êh-pôsihât, êh-otâpêyit.
sentences.text: êkwa awa otêma atimwa awa opwâsîmôw ayinânêw kahkiyaw otâpahêw atâwâkana ê-pôsihât ê-otâpêyit
sentences.english: In addition the Stony hitched up all his eight dogs and loaded the sled with fur and took it.
He did not set out right away.
After three days he set out; he came to the trading-post.

sentences.original: namêskwa kîsi-masinahikêwak, êh-akihtahkik wiyâs pimiyah kâhkêwakwah wiyinwah atâwâkanah, êyikohk êy-ispayiyik.
sentences.text: nam-êskwa kîsi-masinahikêwak ê-akihtahkik wiyâs pimiya kâhkêwakwa wiyinwa atâwâkana iyikohk ê-ispayiyik
sentences.english: They had not yet done writing as they counted the amount of the meat, grease, dried meat, fat, and pelts.
When he arrived, they were still at work.
When he reached the place, they hoisted the flag for him.

sentences.original: pê-nakiskâk, ê-wîh-ati-pîhtokêt iskwâhtêmihk, êh-atamiskawât ôhi nâpêwah êkwah ôh îskwêwah.
sentences.text: pê-nakiskâk ê-wî-ati-pîhtokêt iskwâhtêmihk ê-atamiskawât ôhi nâpêwa êkwa ôhi iskwêwa
sentences.english: They came to meet him, and as he entered the door, he shook hands with the man and his wife.
As he shook hands with them, the cannon was fired.

sentences.original: êkosi, ây, êkwah kêkway kintawêyihtên ? itik.
sentences.english: Then, “Well, and what do you wish for?” he was asked.

sentences.original: hâ, kiyah kitayôwinisah nêwôh ayôwinisah ayîsiyiniwak ta-posiskahkik ê-kaskitêwâkih.
sentences.english: “Of your clothes, four suits for men to wear, black suits.
And, if you have one, a horse.
That is what I want.”

sentences.original: êhag, ntayâwâw pêyak, itik ôh ôkimâwah;
sentences.english: “Very well, I have one,” the agent told him;
“tomorrow they will be brought.”

sentences.original: êkwah ê-wâpaniyik mênikanihk pîhtokêtisahomâwah pôtih mihcêt misatimwah.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-wâpaniyik mênikanihk pîhtokêtisahomâwa pôti mihcêt misatimwa
sentences.english: And in the morning, there, into the paddock were driven a great many horses.
“Well,” said the other to him, “Come here,” said the agent;
“Come and look at this horse,” he said.
He went there; there he saw many horses.

sentences.original: êkwah awaw okimâw ayênâniw ayâwêw atimwah, itêyihtam, aw okimâw.
sentences.english: “So the chief has eight horses,” thought he.

sentences.original: â, itik, ôki misatimwak têpakohp kik-ôtinâwak.
sentences.english: “There,” he told him, “you may take seven of these horses.”

sentences.original: êkwah otinêw; têpakohp misatimwah êkwah otinêw êyakonih.
sentences.text: êkwa otinêw têpakohp misatimwa êkwa otinêw êwakoni
sentences.english: He took them; he took seven of those horses.

sentences.original: haw, pêyak kâ-nitômat misatim, wiyâs kâ-miyiyan.
sentences.english: “Now you asked for one horse for the meat you gave me.

sentences.original: êkoyikô têpipayiw wiyâs, ôkih misatimwak kâ-otinacik.
sentences.english: That meat pays for these horses you have just taken.

sentences.original: hâw, kitatamiskâtin; niya nitêm kimiyitin, êh-atamiskâtân, itêw;
sentences.english: And now I want to make you a present; I give you my own horse as a present,” he told him;

sentences.original: mistahê kitôtên, tâpiskôc niyânan ôtênawah êw-otihtamân, iyikohk kâ-miyiyan mîciwin ahtayak mînah.
sentences.english: “You have done great things; as if I came to five villages is the amount of the food and the pelts you have given me.

sentences.original: êwak ohci namoya kika-nêpêwisin, têkosiniyin ôtah.
sentences.english: Therefore you shall not need to be bashful when you come here.

sentences.original: kiya nîkân kik-âtamiskâtin, namoya kotak awiyak, kiya pikôw.
sentences.english: I shall greet you first of all, no one else, only you.

sentences.original: pêyak okimâwayân kimiyitin. pêyak kiskiwêhon kimiyitin.
sentences.english: A chief's coat I shall give you, and a flag;
these I give you as presents.
So much for that.
And now, what will you take in the way of clothes?”
“Suits for four men.
Also some of your liquor.

sentences.original: êkwah mihkwêkin nêwonisk êkwah kaskitêwêkin nêwinisk.
sentences.english: Also four fathoms of red flannel, and four of black broadcloth.
Also some tobacco.
Also ammunition.
Also various things, such as mirrors and paint.
That is the number of things.”
He was given all of it.
He went into the forest and cut tent-sticks.
After one night he came back;

sentences.original: mitâtaht ayiwâk têpakohp pêtâw apasoyah, ê-kî-pêtât êkwah kâ-miyiht ayôwinisah tahtoh kâ-ntotahk, cistêmâwah, mînah kahkiyaw kêkway kâ-miyiht awâ kâ-kitimâkisit.
sentences.text: mitâtaht ayiwâk têpakohp pêtâw apasoya ê-kî-pêtât êkwa kâ-miyiht ayiwinisa tahto kâ-nitotahk cistêmâwa mîna kahkiyaw kêkway kâ-miyiht awa kâ-kitimâkisit
sentences.english: he brought seventeen tentpoles along with the things he had been given, the clothes he had asked for, the tobacco, and all the things he had been given, that poor man.
He went home; he reached their dwelling.
It was already the time of thaw; spring had come.
Then  accordingly he hunted buffalo.
Quickly did he kill them.

sentences.original: nîsosâp êkwah osihtâw aw îskwêw pahkêkinwah; kîsihtâw.
sentences.text: nîsosâp êkwa osîhtâw awa iskwêw pahkêkinwa kîsihtâw
sentences.english: Then the woman prepared twelve hides; she finished them.
Then they sewed them, making a tent.
The leaves were already budding when they set up their tent;

sentences.original: êkwah cîkâskwahpitamwak ômâ mihkwêkin mîna ôma kaskitêwêkin.
sentences.text: êkwa cîkâskwahpitamwak ôma mihkwêkin mîna ôma kaskitêwêkin
sentences.english: they tied that red cloth and black cloth to the poles.
When night fell, he had finished arranging his belongings.
Then they went into the tent and sat there.
“Put on your good clothes,” he told his wife.

sentences.original: postayôwinisêw aw îskwêw, awa mîna nâpêw.
sentences.text: postayôwinisêw awa iskwêw awa mîna nâpêw
sentences.english: The woman dressed up, and so did the man.
Then they drank that whiskey.

sentences.original: kêkâc ê-wâpaniyik, âh, pôni-minihkwêtân, itêw owîkimâkanah.
sentences.english: When it was almost daybreak, “Now, let us stop drinking,” he said to his wife.

sentences.original: êh-wâpaniyik, âh, êkwah ka-picinânaw; ka-ntônawânawak ayîsiyiniwak, itêw owîkimâkanah.
sentences.english: At daybreak, “There, now we shall move camp; we shall look for some people,” he said to her.
So they moved camp.
All day long they marched.

sentences.original: âskaw minahôw, mîciwin êy-osihtâcik pahkêkin mînah.
sentences.text: âskaw minahôw mîciwin ê-osihtâcik pahkêkin mîna
sentences.english: At times he killed game, and they prepared stored food and hides.
Then, when the heat of the day had come, they saw some tents.

sentences.original: âh, ayôwêpitân ôtah, itêw wîwa awa kâ-kîhkitimâkisit.
sentences.english: “Well, let us stop and rest here,” said he who had been poor to his wife.
Presently they saw a man on horseback, on a hill.
He took a mirror and flashed signals to him.
The young man approached.

sentences.original: hâh, awa êh-takosihk aw ôskinîkiw, êh-kitâpamât, êyôkw âwa kâh-kîh-kitimâkisit, itêyihtam.
sentences.text: hâh awa ê-takosihk awa oskinîkiw ê-kitâpamât itêyihtam
sentences.english: When this young man looked at them, “This is he who once was poor,” was his thought.

sentences.original: êkosi mâka êyakô êkwah kakwêcimâw, êkotah ciy ayâw anah kâ-kîh-mânah-wîkihkêmowak ?
sentences.english: Thereupon that man asked him, “Is he over there with whom I used to stay?”
“Yes, he is there.”
“And he from whom I bought the dogs?”
“Yes, he is there.”
“And the chief from whom I bought tanning implements?”
“Yes, he is over there.”
“And the chief from whom I bought a gun?”
“He is over there.
All the people are over there.”
“Very well, ride back.

sentences.original: êwakonik aniki nêwo anik ôkimâwak kita-pêy-itohtêwak ôtah, ôm êtah k-âyiwêpiyân.
sentences.english: Let those four chiefs come here where I am halting.”
“Yes.”

sentences.original: êkâya mâka kotak awiyak kita-pêy-itohtêw; êwakonik pikô êkwah kiyah, itêw.
sentences.english: “But let no one else come here; only they and you,” he told him.
“Yes.”

sentences.original: sipwêhtêw; kîwêpayiw; kahkiyaw nêwô ntomêw ôh ayîsiyiniwah.
sentences.text: sipwêhtêw kîwêpayiw kahkiyaw nêwo nitomêw ôhi ayîsiyiniwa
sentences.english: He went away; he rode back; he called all four of those men.

sentences.original: nêmah k-ôsêhcâk, k-âwâsitêk nêma, êkotê êh-ohcih-ntomikawiyêk.
sentences.english: “Yonder hill, just beyond it, that is from where the invitation comes to you.”
Accordingly they mounted and rode to that place.
They came to that man who had been poor.
They wondered at him.

sentences.original: mistahê ê-kih-kitimâkisit awa k-êsinâkosit kâ-wêyôtisit, itêyihtamwak ôk ôkimâwak nêwô.
sentences.english: “He who was so very poor, here he is looking like this, a wealthy man,” thought those four chiefs.
He took the clothes.
“Do you wear these,” he said to that chief.
He gave him also a fathom's length of twist tobacco.
“Here is smoking-stuff.
I thank you for having given me these dogs,” he said to him.
Then another.
He gave him clothing from whom he had bought hide-scrapers and other women's utensils.

sentences.original: hâw, ôhi postayôwinisê, êh-miyât, êkwah pêyakonisk cistêmâw, awa pîhtwâkan, itêw.
sentences.english: “Now, take these to wear,” and he gave them to him, together with a fathom's length of tobacco; “Here is something to smoke,” he told him.
Then he took some more.

sentences.original: ôma pâskisikan kâ-kîh-atâmât, hâw, ôhê postayôwinisêh, itêw; awa mînah pîhtwâkan.
sentences.english: To him from whom he had bought the gun, “There, do you wear these,” he said; “And here is smoking-stuff.”
He told them how he had done.

sentences.original: anohc kâ-piponiyik kîh-kîsihtâwâw êwakôw oma kê-wâpahtamêk ôhi êkwah kâ-miyitakok.
sentences.english: “This winter I have paid him for all this which you see here, and these things which I have given you.
sentences.footnote: LB on {kîh-kîsihtâwâw}: Wrongly recorded; probably I overheard the prefix {ni-}: “I”.

sentences.english: He called me 'Chief.'”
“So be it; you shall be chief.

sentences.original: tahtoh kâ-tipêyihtamân mîkiwâhpah kahkiyaw kimiyitin, ta-tipêyihtaman, itik kahkiyaw ôhi nêwô okimâwah.
sentences.english: As many tents as are under me, I give them all to you to command,” he was told by each of those four chiefs.
Then he moved camp to that place.

sentences.original: êw-otihtahk ê-wîhkwêstêyikih mîkiwâhpah, pîhtêyisk ntawi-manokêyiwa ôh ôkimâwa, êh-atoskâkot.
sentences.text: ê-otihtahk ê-wîhkwêstêyiki mîkiwâhpa pîhtêyask nitawi-mânokêyiwa ôhi okimâwa ê-atoskâkot
sentences.english: When he came to where the tents stood in a circle, those chieftains set up a lodge in the center, doing the work for him.

sentences.original: osâm mistah ê-kî-kitimâkisit mâskôc mistahê k-ôh-okimâwit, k-oh-atoskêt.
sentences.text: osâm mistahi ê-kî-kitimâkisit mâskôc mistahi kâ-ôh-okimâwit kâ-ôh-atoskêt
sentences.english: No doubt it was because he had been so poor, that he became chief, that he worked.
That is all.
